name_generic: Extended producer responsibility (EPR) on packaging waste
responsible_authority: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management is responsible for EPR legislation in the Netherlands. The Human Environment and Transport Inspection (HETI) is tasked with the enforcement of this legislation and The Producer Responsible Organisation (PRO) for packaging is called Verpact.
summary: The Netherlands enforces an Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) scheme for packaging waste, including plastic packaging, under Directive 94/62/EG and the 2014 Packaging Decree. The aim of the scheme is to address the growing amount of packaging waste that is causing environmental issues and ensures that producers and importers are collecting and recycling the packaging used. Producers and importers must report packaging types marketed in the Netherlands and pay a Packaging Waste Management Contribution to an independent Producer Responsibilty Organisation (PRO), being Verpact. Contributions are based on material types and quantities, with a 50,000 kg threshold for regular packaging. Compliance involves monthly contributions, as well as annual and monthly reporting on packaging weights and materials.
scope: The Dutch EPR legislation for packaging applies to individuals or entities that place products with packaging on the market or import packaged products into the Netherlands, when they exceed 50.000 kg of packaging per calendar year. This includes those who commission the packaging of products with their own branding, or who add packaging to products when they are provided to the user. It also includes foreign sellers who deliver packaged products directly to Dutch consumers through distance sales. Packaging is any material used to wrap, protect, and deliver products, and it can be made from different materials like plastic, paper, metal, etc. There are three types of packaging: sales or primary packaging, grouping or secondary packaging, and shipping or tertiary packaging.
responsible_party: The Dutch EPR legislation for packaging applies to the party placing the packaging onto the market (i.e. importer, seller, manufacturer, distributor).

registration_requirements.description: The CSRD introduces regulatory reporting requirements relating to the material topics of an organisation. The European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) define how companies need report on various environmental, social and governance topics. The requirements under each topical standard relate to respective appropriate policies, actions, and targets to steer on material impacts, risks and opportunities that were identified. ESRS S2 defines what and how companies need to report on workers in the value chain.
registration_requirements.trigger: If a company falls in scope of the CSRD and has determined based on the double materiality assessment that workers in the value chain is a material topic. The company has to report on the topic in accordance with the requirements set out in ESRS S2.

registration_requirements.language: Language that the Member State accepts
registration_requirements.deadline: Same date as the annual report

The CSRD will cover all large companies that meet two of the following three criteria:

1) turnover exceeding €50 million per year
2) a balance sheet total of more than €25 million
3) more than 250 employees (averaged over a year)

Phase in:
The obligation to report according to the new standards will apply to:

- companies already covered by the NFRD as of fiscal year 2024

This subsidiary exemption also applies to subsidiaries that are public interest entities unless they reach the large company thresholds.

Exempted subsidiaries must include the following in their annual report:

the name and registered office of the parent company that is reporting the sustainability information at group level;
the web links to the consolidated annual report; and
a reference to this exemption in their own annual report.

regulatory_requirements.description: The forced labor regulation introduces regulatory requirements to prevent the import and export of products made with forced labor in the EU. The FLR does not introduce new or additional due diligence requirements.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_authority: TBD per Member State
regulatory_requirements.trigger: When authorities have a suspicion of forced labour, companies must be able to demonstrate that their goods are not the result of forced labour to avoid products being banned from the EU market.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_party: Economic operator. An economic operator is understood to be any natural or legal person or association of persons who is placing or making products available on the EU market or exporting products from the EU.
regulatory_requirements.key_actions: Companies need to have policies and processes in place to monitor and address any instances of forced labour or child labour in their supply chains. These policies and processes help companies to ensure that they are able to demonstrate that their products are free from forced labour or child labour.
regulatory_requirements.deadline: After an investigation has been initiated, the, economic operators have to provide the requested information between 30 and 60 working days. The competent authority will determine what the actual deadline is.
regulatory_requirements.sanctions: In principle, if products are found to have been produced with forced labour, the competent local authority may impose penalties and require the products to be removed from the entire EU market. The products must then either be donated, recycled or disposed of. Additionally, customs authorities will be carrying out controls on products entering and leaving the EU to ensure that products made or suspected to have been made with forced labour will not be imported or exported.

summary: The Forced Labour Regulation prohibits the sale, import, and export of any good that is made using forced labour or child labour. This ban applies to products across all sectors, types and categories when at any stage of the supply chain forced labour or child labour is used. As such, to prevent supply chain disruptions and prepare for this legislation companies operating on the EU markets should ensure that no forced labour or child labour occurs within their supply chains.

regulatory_requirements.key_actions:
Companies need to conduct risk-based human rights due diligence in line with the UNGP's and OECD MNE guidelines by carrying out the following actions:

(a) integrating due diligence into their policies and risk management systems in accordance

(b) identifying and assessing actual or potential adverse impacts in accordance with Article 8 and, where necessary, prioritising actual and potential adverse impacts.

(c)preventing and mitigating potential adverse impacts, and bringing actual adverse impacts to an end and minimising their extent.

(d) providing remediation for actual adverse impacts.

(e) carrying out meaningful engagement with stakeholders.

(f) establishing and maintaining a notification mechanism and a complaints procedure.

(g) monitoring the effectiveness of their due diligence policy and measures.

(h) publicly communicating on due diligence.

regulatory_requirements.description: The aim of this directive is to ensure equal work for equal pay and pay transparency prior to employment as well as to secure the right to information of the employees during the employment.

regulatory_requirements.responsible_party: Employers in public and private sectors.
regulatory_requirements.key_actions:
Companies need to have structures in place to ensure equal pay for equal work and work of equal value.

Companies need to provide prospective job applicants with information about: the initial pay or its range, based on objective, gender-neutral criteria, to be attributed for the position concerned; and (b) where applicable, the relevant provisions of the collective agreement applied by the employer in relation to the position.

Employers shall make easily accessible to their workers the criteria that are used to determine workers’ pay, pay levels and pay progression. Those criteria shall be objective and gender neutral.

If requested by a worker, an employer needs to provide in writing information on their individual pay level and the average pay levels, broken down by sex, for categories of workers performing the same work as them or work of equal value to theirs.

Employers shall provide any information shared with workers or applicants for employment described above in a format which is accessible to persons with disabilities and which takes into account their particular needs.
regulatory_requirements.deadline:

The information requested by the job applicant needs to be made available before the job interview.

summary:
The EU taxonomy is a cornerstone of the EU’s sustainable finance framework and an important market transparency tool. It helps direct investments to the economic activities most needed for the transition, in line with the European Green Deal objectives. The taxonomy is a classification system that defines criteria for economic activities that are aligned with a net zero trajectory by 2050 and the broader environmental goals other than climate (e.g. human rights). To be defined as a sustainable economic activity an economic activity has to meet 4 overarching conditions.
An activity performed by the company can only be Taxonomy-aligned, i.e. environmentally sustainable, when it meets minimum safeguards in the area of minimum international human rights such as the UN Framework on Business and Human Rights.​

reporting_requirements.description: The regulation mandates reporting obligations, such as the duty to inform the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority or the Petroleum Safety Authority in case of suspected breaches of the general application regulations.
reporting_requirements.responsible_authority: Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority or the Petroleum Safety Authority
reporting_requirements.trigger:
The main supplier is required to ensure that the wages and working conditions of the company's subcontractors comply with the applicable general regulations. This duty extends to all links in the subcontracting chain, including hired workers.

Buyers engaged in commercial activities must ensure that their direct suppliers, who do not use subcontractors, adhere to the general regulations.

When work is carried out within the scope of a universalization regulation, the contracting authority (either company or governmental organization) must inform contractors or subcontractors about the wage and labor conditions that follow from these regulations.
reporting_requirements.responsible_party: The responsible party in this regulation is the main supplier, who must ensure compliance with wage and labor conditions among subcontractors, and the buyer or customer in commercial activities, who has a similar duty towards suppliers without subcontractors, with a special rule applying to owners or operators in the petroleum sector.
reporting_requirements.deadline: The regulation does not specify a concrete due date by which the responsible party must comply with the reporting requirements; instead, it outlines the duty of inspection and the obligation to ensure compliance with general regulations continuously as part of contractual operations.
reporting_requirements.retainment_of_records: Contracting authorities (entities that enter into contracts) must ensure compliance with general regulations by maintaining records of wage and labor conditions for subcontractors and contractors, and they must archive documentation that verifies compliance, including any contractual obligations and spot checks conducted to fulfill their duty of inspection.
reporting_requirements.threshold: N/A 'The responsibility for oversight lies with the main suppliers or orderers, who are tasked with ensuring that subcontractors and contractors comply with the agreed-upon wage and labor conditions. This inspection duty is comprehensive, encompassing every level of the subcontracting chain, including temporary workers. The regulations empower authorities to request proof of compliance and suggest the incorporation of contractual penalties for any instances of non-compliance.
reporting_requirements.sanctions:
While the main supplier or orderer is not directly responsible for the employees' pay and working conditions, they are encouraged to implement contractual sanctions for non-compliance with the general application regulations.

If breaches are discovered, it is recommended that the contracting authority notify the Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority or the Petroleum Safety Authority.
reporting_requirements.exemptions: The regulations apply in areas where there is a universalized collective agreement, and the duty of inspection is mandatory for those operating a business, but not for ordinary consumers. The regulation suggests that while there is no formal exemption, there may be flexibility in how the duty of inspection is fulfilled, particularly when dealing with known, reputable suppliers or subcontractors. However, this flexibility does not constitute an exemption from the requirement itself.

regulatory_requirements.description: The regulation encompasses a broad range of rules and standards that govern the activities of main suppliers, buyers, and operators. These include ensuring compliance with wage and labor conditions, health, safety, and environmental standards.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_authority: The Norwegian Labour Inspection Authority and the Petroleum Safety Authority.
regulatory_requirements.trigger: When a main supplier engages with subcontractors, they verify the subcontractors' compliance with prevailing wage and working condition standards. This responsibility extends throughout the entire subcontracting chain, ensuring that even the hired workers are treated fairly according to general regulations. Conversely, when commercial activities are conducted without the involvement of subcontractors, buyers must be vigilant in ensuring that their direct suppliers are also in compliance with these regulations. Additionally, in scenarios where work falls under the purview of universalised collective agreements, it is the duty of the contracting authority to inform all contractors or subcontractors of the specific wage and labor conditions mandated by such agreements.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_party: The main supplier, buyers in commercial activities, and owners/operators in the petroleum sector are all responsible for ensuring compliance with the information requirements regarding wages and working conditions of subcontractors and suppliers.
regulatory_requirements.key_actions:
Establish systems and procedures to investigate and follow up on compliance with general regulations regarding wages and working conditions.

Include clauses in contracts that mandate compliance with general application regulations and follow up by obtaining documentation of employees' wage and labor conditions.

Exercise a duty of care towards suppliers and subcontractors, ensuring that all links in the supply chain, including hired workers, comply with the applicable regulations.

Inform contractors or subcontractors about the wage and labor conditions stipulated by the general application regulations.

Request and review documentation from contractors and subcontractors to verify compliance with wage and labor conditions.

Consider including contractual sanctions for non-compliance with the general application regulations and notify relevant authorities if breaches are discovered.

The responsible party must also be aware that the duty of inspection does not transfer the employer's responsibility for ensuring compliance with wage and labor conditions to them. However, they must take appropriate measures to ensure that contractors and subcontractors fulfill their obligations under the general application regulations.
regulatory_requirements.sanctions: If a breach of the applicable regulations on general application is discovered, the main supplier/purchaser has no obligation to implement sanctions against the company that has not fulfilled its obligations. registration_requirements.description:
Economic operators who make available any packaging for the first time on the market of a Member State must register with a national register that each Member State must introduce. 

Without this registration, the economic operator shall not be allowed to make their packaging available on the market of a Member State.
registration_requirements.responsible_authority: The authority responsible for the enforcement of the registration requirement is the competent authority designated by each Member State.
registration_requirements.trigger: In principle, the obligation to comply with the registration requirements lies with the producer. They need to comply with this requirement prior to placing packaging or packaged products on the market within a Member State. Producers who are not registered within a Member State, shall not make available packaging on the market of this Member State.
registration_requirements.responsible_party: The responsible party for the registration requirements is the producer of packaging, defined as any manufacturer, importer or distributor who makes available packaging for the first time on the market of a Member State. When applicable, the obligation to register the producer may shift to a PRO or to an authorised representative of the producer.
registration_requirements.data_elements:
As a producer of packaging, you must register in the register of each Member State where you make packaging available on the market for the first time. The information required for this registration will include: 
- identification details (name, registered trade name or registered trade mark as well as their postal address and, where available, electronic means of communication through which it can be contacted),
- if applicable, the identification details of the authorised representative.
- Information on how the producer meets their extended producer responsiblity obligations. 

More detailed information on the format for the registration is still expected to follow seperatey after the entry into force of the Regulation.
registration_requirements.payment_obligations: Member States may charge a fee to process the application for a registration of a producer. Such fees must be cost-based and proportionate. Nevertheless, the exact amount and modalities of such fees may vary depending on the Member State and the competent authority.
registration_requirements.deadline: The producer of packaging must comply with the registration requirements before making packaging available on the market of a Member State for the first time. The registration must be granted within 12 weeks of providing all the necessary information to the competent authority of the Member State.
registration_requirements.sanctions: Member States will lay down the rules on penalties applicable to infringements, including for failure to register prior to placing packaging on the market of the Member State

reporting_requirements.responsible_authority:

Depending on the Member State, reporting obligations to the producer responsibility organisation will apply for the extended producer responsiblity scheme. 

Additionally, producers of packaging are subject to annual reporting requirements under the PPWR to the competent authorities in the Member States where they place packaging on the markets. The report must include information on the amounts and types of packaging placed on the market and the recycling rates achieved.

- the reporting period

reporting_requirements.exemptions: Member States will lay down the rules on penalties applicable to infringements, including for failure to meet reporting obligations under PPWR.

regulatory_requirements.description: The PPWR sets regulatory requirements with design and sustainability requirements. The main objectives of these regulatory requirements are to prevent or reduce the environmental impact of packaging and packaging waste, and to promote reuse, recovery, and recycling of packaging materials.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_authority: Each Member State will assign their own competent authority to enforce the regulatory requirements.
regulatory_requirements.trigger: Packaging made available on the EU market must meet the regulatory requirements.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_party: The PPWR defines economic operators as the responsible parties for various obligations related to packaging and packaging waste. Economic operators include manufacturers, suppliers, importers, distributors, authorised representatives, final distributors, and fulfilment service providers of packaging or packaged products.
regulatory_requirements.key_actions:
The regulatory requirements include:
- To ensure that packaging complies with the sustainability requirements, manufactures must perform an assessment and draw up an EU declaration of conformity when their packaging complies. Without this declaration of conformity packaging is not allowed on the EU market. 
- All packaging placed on the market in the EU must be recyclable, contain  a minimum percentage of recycled content for plastic packaging and, where appropiate be compostable.
- Specific labelling will be required for packaging regarding the material composition, sorting instructions and, where applicable, reuse instructions. 
- For several types of packaging, such as transport packaging and packaging used in e-commerce, reuse and refill targets are introduced. 
- Packaging must be designed so that its weight and volume is reduced to the minimum necessary.
- A ban is introduced for certain plastic packaging. Among others, this ban will include plastic shrink wrap and collation film to group products together, some plastic packaging for fresh fruit and vegetables, as well as individual sachets for example for sauces and preserves and very light weight plastic bags.
regulatory_requirements.threshold: The PPWR will enter into effect in various stages. As a result the regulatory requirements will enter into effect of the course of multiple years between 2026 and 2030. Afterwards some of the targets set in these regulatory requirements (i.e. targets on recyclablity, recycled content or reuse and refill) will become more stringent in the years after 2030.
regulatory_requirements.sanctions:
The producer of packaging is subject to various sanctions for non-compliance :
- The prohibition to place on the market packaging that does not comply with the sustainability requirements, such as recyclability, recycled content, compostability, and minimisation of substances of concern.
- The obligation to take corrective measures, such as bringing the packaging into conformity, withdrawing it or recalling it, in case of non-compliance with the sustainability or labelling requirements.
The obligation to pay modulated fees to the extended producer responsibility schemes based on the recyclability and recycled content of the packaging.

Nevertheless, Member States will lay down the rules on penalties applicable to infringements, including for failure to meet the regulatory obligations of PPWR.

summary: The PPWR is designed to modernize and harmonize packaging regulations, thereby reducing environmental impact, fostering a circular economy, and enhancing the internal market's efficiency. The PPWR establishes ambitious goals, such as preventing the generation of packaging waste, ensuring all EU market packaging is recyclable by 2030, increasing recycled plastics in packaging to replace virgin materials, and mandating deposit return systems for plastic bottles and aluminum cans. It introduces stringent measures for packaging design, reuse, recycling, and labelling, alongside reporting obligations. Additionally, the PPWR aims to prevent waste generation, reduce packaging volumes, and promote reuse and refill systems. It also focuses on preventing excessive packaging, encouraging green public procurement, and standardizing labelling for correct disposal.
scope:
The proposed PPWR applies a broad definition of packaging. A limited number of exemptions apply, but in principle packaging is defined as items of any materials that are intended to be used for the containment, protection, handling, delivery or presentation of products. 

The PPWR applies to any economic operator who makes packaging available on the market within the territory of a Member State, whether as self-standing packaging or as the packaging for a product. Such an operator is considered the producer of the packaging and, among others, has to meet the extended producer responsibility obligations for the packaging waste management. The PPWR also applies to manufacturers of packaging, as well as importers or distributors who place packaging on the market under their own name or trademark or modify packaging already placed on the market in a way that may affect its compliance with the PPWR.
responsible_party:
The PPWR applies to various parties that are involved in the supply chain of packaging and packaged products on the EU market. These parties are defined as economic operators and include manufacturers, suppliers, importers, distributors, authorised representatives, final distributors, and fulfilment service providers of packaging or packaged products. 

The PPWR defines producers as manufacturers, importers, or distributors who make packaging available for the first time on the market of a Member State. This applies irrespective of the selling method and therefore includes distance sales. When a producer is not established in the relevant Member State they can be obligated to appoint an authorised representative to fulfil their obligations on their behalf. 

Finally, the PPWR also applies to online platforms that allow consumers to conclude distance contracts with producers. These online platforms must collect information from the producers before allowing them to conclude sales via their platform.

Instead, the obligation to register with the Central Agency applies to manufacturers of packaging filled with goods before the packaging is placed on the market for the first time. The Central Agency must be notified immediately of any changes to registration data and the permanent cessation of manufacturing activities.
registration_requirements.sanctions:
A fine of up to EUR 100.000 may be imposed on anyone who wilfully or negligently fails to register, fails to register correctly, fails to register in full or fails to register on time in breach of the obligation to register with the ZSVR.
A fine of up to EUR 10.000 may be imposed on anyone who wilfully or negligently fails to notify the ZSVR or fails to do so correctly, completely or on time.

data_elements: Reporting includes information on the type and quantity as well as the relevant time period.
reporting_requirements.description: The reporting obligation includes, among other things, the reporting of the following information: participations made or expected, any deductions from packaging quantities due to refunds, breakdown of material type and mass of packaging, allocation by manufacturer, stating the respective registration number.
reporting_requirements.responsible_authority: Stiftung Zentrale Stelle Verpackungsregister - ZSVR (engl. Central Agency Packaging Register).
reporting_requirements.trigger: Placing packagage on the market.
reporting_requirements.responsible_party: Producers and distributors of packaging.
reporting_requirements.frequency:
The notification is made electronically to the ZSVR:
1. By the 15th calendar day of the last month of the current quarter, the expected mass of packaging involved for the following quarter (interim report).
2. By 1 June of each year, the mass of packaging actually involved for the previous calendar year (annual report).
reporting_requirements.deadline: nan
reporting_requirements.threshold: The reporting obligation of the systems requires a system. The operation of a system requires authorisation from the competent state authority. Authorisation is granted upon application if a system fulfils the requirements.
reporting_requirements.sanctions:
A fine of up to EUR 100.000 may be imposed on any person who wilfully or negligently fails to submit a volume flow statement to the ZSVR or fails to do so correctly, completely, in the prescribed manner or on time in breach of the reporting obligation; fails to submit a declaration of completeness or fails to do so correctly, completely or on time; fails to submit an interim report and/or annual report or fails to do so correctly, completely or on time.
A fine of up to EUR 10.000 may be imposed on anyone who wilfully or negligently fails to submit information to the ZSVR or fails to do so correctly, completely or on time.

regulatory_requirements.description: The regulatory requirements include the obligation to participate in a waste collection and disposal system of collecting, sorting and recycling of package, labelling, take-back and utilisation obligations. We do not see these requirements as reporting obligations but as general regulatory and organisational requirements. These also arise directly from the VerpackG in various places.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_authority: Stiftung Zentrale Stelle Verpackungsregister - ZSVR (engl. Central Agency Packaging Register).
regulatory_requirements.trigger: Placing packaging on the market.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_party: Manufacturer and distributor of packaging.
regulatory_requirements.key_actions: Fulfilment of reporting obligations as set by regulation via online plattform and participation in a system supporting  waste disposal ("duales System"); In principle, manufacturers of packaging that is subject to system participation must participate in one or more systems with this packaging to ensure nationwide take-back before it is placed on the market. Packaging subject to system participation is sales and secondary packaging filled with goods that typically accumulates as waste with private end consumers after use.
regulatory_requirements.deadline: No specific deadline; Reporting must be performed immediately.
regulatory_requirements.sanctions:
A fine of up to EUR 200.000 may be imposed on anyone who wilfully or negligently, contrary to the provisions of the Packaging Act, fails to participate in a system, fails to participate correctly or fails to participate fully; promises or grants a fee or an advantage; fails to ensure the collection of empty packaging; fails to recycle the waste collected by systems correctly; operates a system without special authorisation.
A fine of up to  EUR 10.000 may be imposed on anyone who wilfully or negligently uses a number or abbreviation contrary to the provisions of the Packaging Act; fails to provide a notification or fails to do so correctly, completely or in good time; fails to provide a statement or fails to do so correctly, completely or in good time; places a non-returnable plastic drinks bottle on the market; refunds a deposit without taking back the packaging; does not provide a notice or does not provide it correctly; does not offer a product in reusable packaging; offers a sales unit at a higher price or under worse conditions or does not provide a notice correctly, completely or in the prescribed manner.
A fine of up to EUR 100.000 may be imposed on anyone who wilfully or negligently places packaging or a packaging component on the market contrary to the provisions of the Packaging Act; offers packaging for sale or enables packaging to be offered for sale; provides an activity referred to in section 3 (14c) sentence 1 contrary to section 7 (7) sentence 3 first half-sentence or section 9 (5) sentence 3, fails to make a notification or fails to make it correctly, completely or on time; fails to submit a proof of volume flow, or fails to do so correctly, completely, in the prescribed manner or on time; fails to register, or fails to do so correctly, completely or on time; fails to submit a declaration of completeness, or fails to do so correctly, completely or on time; fails to take back packaging referred to in section 15(1) sentence 1, also in conjunction with subsection (5) sentence 1; contrary to § 15 paragraph 2 sentence 2, also in conjunction with paragraph 5 sentence 1, does not provide a notice, does not provide it correctly or does not provide it completely; contrary to § 15 paragraph 3 sentence 1 or paragraph 5 sentence 3, does not correctly reuse or recycle packaging referred to therein; contrary to § 15 paragraph 3 sentence 3, also in conjunction with § 31 paragraph 3 sentence 3, or § 15 paragraph 5 sentence 5, does not provide evidence, does not provide it correctly, does not provide it completely or does not provide it in the prescribed manner; does not submit a report, does not submit it correctly, completely or in time; does not submit a report, does not submit it correctly, completely or in time; does not collect a deposit; does not label a single-use beverage container correctly, correctly or in time; does not take back a single-use beverage container or does not refund the deposit; does not properly recycle a returned single-use beverage container, does not participate in a nationwide deposit system.

responsible_authority: Stiftung Zentrale Stelle Verpackungsregister - ZSVR (engl. Central Agency Packaging Register).
summary: Transfer of product responsibility for packaging materials to producers with the aim to reduce waste and promote circularity.
scope: The scope of application includes all packaging. The definition of packaging is as follows: Packaging is a product made of any material for the containment, protection, handling, delivery or presentation of goods, which may range from raw materials to processed products, passed from the manufacturer to the distributor or end user.
responsible_party: Any company which produces and distributes packaging.

registration_requirements.description: Registration requirements depend on the kind of waste and hazardous material that is handled (may vary).
registration_requirements.responsible_authority:
There is no central supervisory authority. At federal level, the Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Nuclear Safety and Consumer Protection (BMUV) is responsible;
At state level, the environmental authorities of the respective federal states; at municipal level, the municipal waste disposal authorities.
registration_requirements.responsible_party:
Producers and distributors are only obliged to notify the competent authority if they voluntarily take back products and the waste generated after use of the products in their own facilities or in facilities of third parties commissioned by them. They must notify the competent authority of this before commencing the take-back.
In addition, only the operator of a landfill is obliged to notify the competent authority.

data_elements:
The proof is provided
1. before the start of disposal in the form of a declaration by the producer, owner, collector or carrier of waste for the planned disposal, a declaration of acceptance by the waste disposal company and confirmation of the permissibility of the planned disposal by the competent authority, and
2. on the disposal carried out or parts of the disposal in the form of declarations by the parties obliged under sentence 1 on the whereabouts of the disposed waste.
reporting_requirements.description: The Act provides for a number of reporting obligations aimed at ensuring transparency and control in waste management. These reporting obligations affect various actors along the waste chain, including manufacturers of certain products, landfill operators, waste managers (may vary).
reporting_requirements.responsible_authority:
There is no central supervisory authority. At federal level, the Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Nuclear Safety and Consumer Protection (BMUV) is responsible;
At state level, the environmental authorities of the respective federal states; at municipal level, the municipal waste disposal authorities.
reporting_requirements.trigger: Handling of relevant waste according to the act. Waste is any material or object that its owner disposes of, wishes to dispose of or must dispose of. Waste for recovery is waste that is recovered; waste that is not recovered is waste for disposal.
reporting_requirements.responsible_party: The producers, holders, collectors, transporters and disposers of hazardous waste must provide evidence of the proper disposal of hazardous waste both to the competent authority and to each other.
reporting_requirements.frequency: The Act includes several frequencies depending on the action in question from regular to annual reporting.
reporting_requirements.payment_obligation: No fees are charged by the authorities for the obligation to report. However, fees may be charged for the deposit of waste.
reporting_requirements.deadline: nan
reporting_requirements.retainment_of_records: A legal ordinance must first be issued for this purpose. After that proper waste disposal must be documented and evidence of disposal must be submitted to the authorities if requested by the authorities.
reporting_requirements.threshold: nan
reporting_requirements.sanctions: nan

regulatory_requirements.description: The act defines rules for handling of waste, including duties and due diligence responsibilies for producers.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_authority: There is no central supervisory authority. At federal level, the Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Nuclear Safety and Consumer Protection (BMUV) is responsible; At state level, the environmental authorities of the respective federal states; at municipal level, the municipal waste disposal authorities.
regulatory_requirements.trigger: Handling of relevant waste according the the act.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_party: All natural and legal persons who produce, possess, collect, transport, store, treat, utilise or dispose of waste.
regulatory_requirements.key_actions:
Compliance with the relevant waste related obligations (may vary). For example: Prevention and reduction of waste, § 6, 15 KrWG
Proper waste disposal (principles), § 15 KrWG
Separate collection, § 15 KrWG
Possible take-back obligations, § 25, 26 KrWG
Disposal safety and monitoring, § 27 KrWG
Waste prevention programmes, § 30 KrWG.
regulatory_requirements.deadline:
Ad-hoc;
(on 1. June 2012, the KrWG came into force).
regulatory_requirements.sanctions:
A fine of up to EUR 100.000 may be imposed if hazardous waste is intentionally or negligently mixed, waste is not separated or not separated in time or not treated or not treated in time, a quality or monitoring mark is used without authorisation, waste for disposal is treated, stored or deposited, a landfill site is constructed or significantly modified without a planning approval decision or without planning permission, an enforceable requirement under the KrWG is contravened, an enforceable requirement associated with an authorisation under the KrWG is contravened, an enforceable prohibition under the KrWG is contravened and hazardous waste is collected, transported or traded without a permit.
A fine of up to EUR 10.000 may also be imposed if a mandatory notification is intentionally or negligently not made, not made correctly, not made in full or not made in time, if entry onto a property or a measure specified therein is not tolerated contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, if an emissions declaration is not made, not made correctly, not made in full or not made in time or not made correctly, not made in full or not made in time, or if an emissions declaration is not made, not made correctly, not made in full or not made in time contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, or is not completed correctly, completely or in good time; contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, information is not provided correctly, completely or in good time; contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, entry to a property or a residential, business or operating premises, inspection of a document or the performance of a technical investigation or test is not permitted; contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, a facility specified therein is not made accessible or a worker is not made available, a tool or a document is not made available, an enforceable order under the KrWG is contravened, a register is not kept, not kept correctly or not kept in full, contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, information is not recorded, not recorded correctly, not recorded in full or not recorded in good time, contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, a register is not submitted, not submitted correctly, not submitted in full or not submitted in good time or a notification is not submitted, not submitted correctly, not submitted in full or not submitted in good time, contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, or not made in time, contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, a declaration or document is not kept or not kept for the prescribed period, contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, a record is not kept, not kept correctly, not kept completely or not kept in time, contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, a vehicle is not labelled with warning signs, not labelled correctly, not labelled completely or not labelled in time, contrary to the provisions of the KrWG, a waste representative is not appointed or not appointed in time.

responsible_authority: Different levels of authorities at federal and municipal level.
summary: Promotion of circular economy and ensuring the environmentally sound management of waste.
scope: The provisions of the KrWG apply to the prevention of waste, the recycling of waste, the disposal of waste and other waste management measures. As soon as the holder wants or needs to dispose of waste within the meaning of KrWG.
responsible_party: Any natural and legal persons that performs relevant action under the act, e.g. handling, collection, transportation, storage, disposal of waste.

registration_requirements.description: Manufacturers and distributors of single-use plastic products must register with the Federal Environment Agency before making products available on the market or selling them. Registration is mandatory for anyone who manufactures single-use plastic products within the meaning of this law. Registration includes providing information such as company information, contact person and information on plastic.
registration_requirements.trigger:
Production and distribution of relevant single use plastic products and such products that include plastic.
The definition of single-use plastic product is: a product made entirely or partly of plastic that is not designed, developed and placed on the market to go through multiple product loops during its lifetime by being returned to a manufacturer or distributor for refilling or reused for the same purpose for which it was manufactured.
registration_requirements.responsible_party: Any producer and distributor of relevant single use plastic products.
registration_requirements.data_elements:
The following information must be provided during registration:
- the name, address and contact details of the manufacturer, in particular postcode and town, street and house number, country, telephone number and European or national tax number,
- details of a natural person authorised to represent the manufacturer,
- national identification number and e-mail address of the manufacturer and, in the case of an authorised representative, the same details of the authorised representative,
- brand names under which the manufacturer makes available or sells the single-use plastic products in accordance with Annex 1 (e.g., food containers, bags, beverage containers, beverage cups, plastic carrier bags) on the market for the first time,
- types of single-use plastic products in accordance with Annex 1 (e.g., food containers, bags, beverage containers, beverage cups, plastic carrier bags) made available or sold on the market for the first time
- and a declaration that all the information provided is true.
registration_requirements.deadline: Before the sale and distribution of relevant single use plastic products.
registration_requirements.sanctions:
A fine of up to EUR 100.000 may be imposed on any person who wilfully or negligently:
- fails to register with the Federal Environment Agency,
- fails to register correctly, completely or in good time,
- fails to notify the Federal Environment Agency immediately of any changes to registration data or the permanent cessation of activities,
- makes available or distributes a single-use plastic product on the market for the first time without registration,
- offers a single-use plastic product for sale without registration,
- facilitates the offering of a single-use plastic product without registration or
- as a natural or legal person or partnership with legal capacity that offers at least two of the following services within the scope of this Act as part of a business activity: Storage, packaging, addressing or shipping of single-use plastic products to which it has no ownership right without registration (excluding postal, parcel delivery or other freight transport service providers).

data_elements: From 1. January 2025, manufacturers must notify the Federal Environment Agency by 15. May each year of the single-use plastic products (e.g., food containers, bags, beverage containers, beverage cups, plastic carrier bags) they made available or sold on the market for the first time in the previous calendar year, broken down by type and mass in kilograms. The report must be checked and confirmed by a registered expert.
reporting_requirements.description: Reporting on type and mass of relevant single-use plastic products made available on the market or sold for the first time with focus on the previous calendar year.
reporting_requirements.trigger: Placing relevant single use plastic products on the market. Relevant single-use plastic products are, in particular, food containers, drinks containers with a filling volume of up to 3 litres; lightweight plastic carrier bags; wet wipes; balloons; tobacco products with filters and filters.
reporting_requirements.responsible_party: Any producer and distributor of relevant single use plastic products.
reporting_requirements.payment_obligation: The EKWFondsG does not provide for direct payments to the authority for reporting obligations. However, manufacturers of single-use plastic products, for example, levy a special annual charge in accordance with Annex 1 (e.g., food containers, bags, beverage containers, beverage cups, plastic carrier bags) to reimburse the costs (single-use plastic charge).
reporting_requirements.deadline: Until 15 May of each year for the previous calendar year.
reporting_requirements.retainment_of_records:
From 1 January 2025, manufacturers must notify the Federal Environment Agency by 15 May each year of the single-use plastic products they made available or sold on the market for the first time in the previous calendar year, broken down by type and mass in kilograms. The report must be checked and confirmed by a registered expert.
Although this does not result in an obligation to document the reporting, if there are indications that the report is incorrect or incomplete, the Federal Environment Agency may require the manufacturer to submit further documents necessary for the examination in individual cases. For these reasons, documentation is recommended.
reporting_requirements.threshold: From 1 January 2025 a future annual reporting obligation for manufacturers to the Federal Environment Agency exists irrespective of a minimum weight of single-use plastic products made available or sold on the market for the first time in the previous calendar year.
reporting_requirements.sanctions: From 1 January 2025 a fine of up to EUR 10,000 may be imposed on anyone who wilfully or negligently fails to submit a report or fails to submit it correctly, completely or on time in contravention of the reporting obligation.

regulatory_requirements.description: Obligation to pay an annual special levy to promote sustainability.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_authority: Umweltbundesamt - UBA (eng. Federal Environment Agency)
regulatory_requirements.trigger:
Production and distributation of relevant single use plastic products
Relevant single-use plastic products are, in particular, food containers, i.e. containers, such as boxes with or without lids, for food that is intended to be consumed directly, either on site or as a take-away meal, usually eaten out of the container and can be consumed without further preparation; beverage containers with a filling volume of up to 3 litres; lightweight plastic carrier bags; wet wipes; balloons; tobacco products with filters and filters.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_party: Producer and distributor of relevant single-use plastic products.
regulatory_requirements.key_actions:
Payment of annual financial contribution
When the reporting obligation comes into force on 1 January 2025, manufacturers must report the single-use plastic products they made available or sold on the market for the first time in the previous calendar year to the Federal Environment Agency by 15 May each year, broken down by type and mass in kilograms.
regulatory_requirements.deadline: 4 weeks after receipt of payment notice.
regulatory_requirements.sanctions:
A fine of up to EUR 100.000 may be imposed on any person who wilfully or negligently fails to register with the Federal Environment Agency, fails to register correctly, completely or in good time, fails to notify the Federal Environment Agency immediately of any changes to registration data or the permanent cessation of activities, makes a single-use plastic product available on the market for the first time or distributes it without registration, offers a single-use plastic product for sale without registration, facilitates the offering of a single-use plastic product without registration or as a natural or legal person or partnership with legal capacity that offers at least two of the following services within the scope of this Act as part of a business activity: Storage, packaging, addressing or shipping of single-use plastic products to which it has no ownership right without registration (excluding postal, parcel delivery or other freight transport service providers).
A fine of up to EUR 10.000 may also be imposed on any person who, as a manufacturer not established within the scope of this Act or within the scope of this Act, intentionally or negligently makes available or sells single-use plastic products on the market for the first time in another Member State of the European Union or a signatory state to the Agreement on the European Economic Area in which he is not established, fails to appoint an authorised representative before commencing his activities, or fails to do so correctly or in good time; intentionally or negligently fails to appoint an authorised representative to the Federal Environment Agency, or fails to do so correctly or in good time; or fails to notify the Federal Environment Agency of his intention or negligence in breach of the reporting obligation that will apply from 01.01.2025, fails to submit a notification or fails to do so correctly, completely or on time.

name_generic: German Law on the Reduction of the Impact of Certain Plastic Products on the Environment
responsible_authority: Umweltbundesamt - UBA (eng. Federal Environment Agency)
summary: The Act aims to prevent and minimise the impact of single-use plastic products on the environment and human health and to promote innovative and sustainable business models, products and materials.
scope: The aim of this Act is to prevent and minimise the impact of single-use plastic products (e.g., food containers, bags, beverage containers, beverage cups, plastic carrier bags) on the environment, in particular the marine environment, and human health, and to promote innovative and sustainable business models, products and materials. In order to achieve these waste management objectives, the law is also intended to regulate the market behaviour of the obligated parties.
responsible_party: Producer and distributor of relevant plastic products.

registration_requirements.description: Entities conducting business related to, i.e. the introduction of products in packaging or packaging waste into the Polish market, are subject to the registration in the Polish register before starting their activities.
registration_requirements.trigger: An entrepreneur involved in activities such as being a packaging recovery organization, making intra-Community supplies of products in packaging, exporting packaging or products in packaging, and introducing packaging or products in packaging must be registered accordingly. Additionally, an entrepreneur engaged in the intra-Community supply or export of packaging waste, or conducting recycling or other packaging waste recovery processes intending to issue documents regarding the status of packaging waste (DPO, DPR, EDPO, and EDPR documents).
registration_requirements.responsible_party: Entrepreneur: 1) being a packaging recovery organization, 2) making intra-Community deliveries of products in packaging, 3) exporting: a) packaging, b) products in packaging, 4) introducing packaging, 5) introducing products in packaging, 6) running a retail trade entity or wholesale, which offers plastic shopping bags subject to a recycling fee
registration_requirements.data_elements: Entrepreneur identification data; address; type of activity; specifics related to the packaging activity type (, for example the location in which the packaging waste will be produced, type of business conducted or types of packaging being used)
registration_requirements.payment_obligations:
The registration fee is subject to entry in the register.
Once entered in the register, the entity shall pay the annual fee for a given year. The annual fee is not paid in the year in which the registration fee was paid.
The amount of the registration fee and the annual fee as of today is for: a) micro-entrepreneurs - PLN 100.00; b) entrepreneurs other than the entrepreneurs referred to in point a - PLN 300.00
registration_requirements.deadline: No deadline, however failure to register will result in monetary sanctions
registration_requirements.sanctions: The penalty occurs in two cases. A criminal penalty is imposed on someone who is not registered and issues DPR and EDPR, the penalty ranges from PLN 10,000 to PLN 500,000. In a situation where a legal person distributes products in packages placed on the market by a person placing products in packages that is not entered in the register, with the exception of products in packages that were placed on the market by the person placing the products in packages on the market before the date of deletion from the register; the penalty is from PLN 500 to PLN 20,000.
registration_requirements.exemptions: Does not apply to entrepreneurs in the field of packaging in which they placed products on the market in a given calendar year and then, in the same calendar year, exported or intra-Community delivery of these packagings without the products or with the products.                                                                          a natural person and an organizational unit other than an entrepreneur that uses waste for its own needs, an entity that has land on which municipal sewage sludge is used for: growing plants intended for the production of compost, growing plants not intended for consumption and for the production of feed, an entity that runs a non-professional activity in the field of collecting packaging waste and waste in the form of used consumer products, such as medicines and their packaging, transporting the waste they produce, farmer being a waste producer, managing an area of less than 75 ha.

data_elements: The necessary data to create a report is listed in art. 73 ust. 2 of the Act on Waste i.e. data identifying the entity, the number of lightweight plastic shopping bags placed on the market
reporting_requirements.description: Entrepreneurs are required to file annual reports concerning packaging and packaging waste management to the voivodeship marshal
reporting_requirements.trigger: 1) introducing packaging, 2) exporting packaging, 3) exporting products in packaging, 4) making an intra-Community supply of products in packaging, 5) introducing products in packaging
reporting_requirements.responsible_party: Entrepreneur: 1) introducing packaging, 2) exporting packaging, 3) exporting products in packaging, 4) making an intra-Community supply of products in packaging, 5) introducing products in packaging
reporting_requirements.deadline: Till 15th of March for the report for the year prior
reporting_requirements.retainment_of_records: The documents on the basis of which the reports are prepared are kept for 5 years, counting from the end of the calendar year to which they relate.
reporting_requirements.threshold: nan
reporting_requirements.sanctions: Failure to submit a report or make a correction to the report within the specified deadline is subject to a fine that amounts up to PLN 5,000.

regulatory_requirements.description: The person introducing packaging is obliged to limit the amount and negative impact on the environment of substances used to produce packaging and the generated packaging waste.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_authority: Voivodeship marshal
regulatory_requirements.trigger: Commencement of activities regarding packacing
regulatory_requirements.responsible_party: Entrepreneur: 1) introducing packaging, 2) exporting packaging, 3) exporting products in packaging, 4) making an intra-Community supply of products in packaging, 5) introducing products in packaging
regulatory_requirements.key_actions: An entrepreneur recycling packaging waste is obliged to meet the requirements specified in the Act on waste, including decisions regarding waste management, if required. The person introducing products in beverage packaging in the form of single-use plastic bottles with a capacity of up to three liters is obliged to ensure that these packaging, including their plastic caps and lids, contain an appropriate weight percentage the plastic caps and lids of containers should remain attached to them during the intended use of the beverage. The person placing products in packaging is obliged to keep records in paper or electronic form, including information on the weight of the packaging in which he placed the products on the market in a given calendar year. In the case of a person introducing products in beverage packaging and directly introducing products in beverage packaging, the records additionally include information on the number and capacity of the packaging in which they introduced beverage products to the market, divided into types of packaging.
regulatory_requirements.sanctions: Numerous actions and omissions subject to administrative fines are listed in art. 56 and pertain, for example, to situations where a business, not being registered, issues DPR or EDPR documents; does not limit the quantity and negative environmental impact of substances in such a way that the maximum total content of lead, cadmium, mercury, and hexavalent chromium in packaging does not exceed 100 mg/kg; or introduces packaging into circulation that is designed and manufactured in a way that prevents its reuse and subsequent recycling. Art. 57 assigns various ranges of fines depending on the fulfillment of specific conditions. The minimum amount is 500 PLN, while the maximum reaches 1,000,000 PLN. Criminal liability in the form of a fine (without specified ranges) is also possible under Arts. 59-62.
regulatory_requirements.exemptions: Does not apply to entrepreneurs in the field of packaging in which they placed products on the market in a given calendar year and then, in the same calendar year, exported or intra-Community delivery of these packagings without the products or with the products.

name_local: Ustawa z dnia 13 czerwca 2013 r. o gospodarce opakowaniami i odpadami opakowaniowymi (t.j. Dz. U. z 2024 r. poz. 927 z późn. zm.).
name_generic: Act on Packaging and Packaging Waste Management
responsible_authority: The Minister of Climate and Environment, the Chief Inspector of Environmental Protection, the Voivodeship Marshals, the Municipalities and the National Waste Database
summary: The Act was designed in order to reduce the amount and harmfulness to the environment of materials and substances contained in packaging and packaging waste as well as the amount and harmfulness to the environment of packaging and packaging waste at the stage of the production process, placing on the market, distribution and processing, in particular by producing clean products and using clean technologies. The Act is also a partial transposition into the Polish legal order of Directive (EU) 2019/904 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 June 2019 on the reduction of the impact of certain plastic products on the environment ("SUP Directive"); aims to reduce the amount and harmfulness to the environment of materials and substances contained in packaging and packaging waste, as well as the amount and harmfulness to the environment of packaging and packaging waste at the stage of the production process, marketing, distribution and processing, in particular by producing clean products and using clean technologies.
scope: The subject of the act is packaging, which is defined as any product made of any material, used for the containment, protection, handling, delivery or presentation of goods, from the producer to the user or consumer, including all disposable items used for the same purposes. The act also covers packaging waste, which is any packaging or packaging material that is discarded by the user or consumer, or that is no longer used for its intended purpose.
responsible_party: The producers and importers of packaging and packaged goods, the distributors of packaging and packaged goods, users of packaging and packaged goods and  the entities that collect, transport, sort, recover or dispose of packaging waste.

registration_requirements.description: Registration applies to entities that operate in the field of specific types of products, including: single-use plastic products.
registration_requirements.trigger: a) placing products on the market, b) operating a retail trade unit, wholesale trade unit or catering unit offering single-use plastic products, c) recovering or recycling waste arising from products, d) exporting and intra-Community delivery of waste arising from products for the purpose of recovery or recycling; e) operating port waste reception facilities or an entrepreneur operating other equivalent collection systems
registration_requirements.data_elements: Entrepreneur identification data; address; type of activity; specifics related to the products introducing activity type, for example the types of single-use plastics products, type of business, if there’s agreement with the recovery organization
registration_requirements.payment_obligations:
The registration fee is subject to entry in the register.
Once entered in the register, entity shall pay the annual fee for a given year. The annual fee is not paid in the year in which the registration fee was paid.
The amount of the registration fee and the annual fee as of today is for: a) micro-entrepreneurs - PLN 100.00; b) entrepreneurs other than the entrepreneurs referred to in point a - PLN 300.00.
registration_requirements.deadline: No deadline, however failure to register will result in monetary sanctions
registration_requirements.sanctions: Failure to apply for entry in the register, for change of entry in the register or for deletion from the register or submits an application that is inconsistent with the facts, shall be subject to the penalty of arrest or a fine. The fine might be up to 1 mln PLN.
registration_requirements.exemptions: Natural person and an organizational unit other than an entrepreneur that uses waste for its own needs, an entity that has land on which municipal sewage sludge is used for: growing plants intended for the production of compost, growing plants not intended for consumption and for the production of feed, an entity that runs a non-professional activity in the field of collecting packaging waste and waste in the form of used consumer products, such as medicines and their packaging, transporting the waste they produce, farmer being a waste producer, managing an area of less than 75 ha.

data_elements: The necessary data to create a report is listed in art. 73 ust. 2 of the Act on Waste i.e. entrepreneurs are obliged to submit annual reports on the weight of packaging placed on the market, the weight of recovered or recycled packaging waste and actions taken to reduce the weight of packaging. regulatory_requirements.description: The Waste Law introduces the requirement to obtain authorizations for facilities where certain activities are carried out, as well as notifications for other specific operations.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_authority: Ministry for the ecological transition and the demographic challenge
regulatory_requirements.trigger:
Authorization: The facilities that carry out operations triggering the obligation to obtain authorization and notification (which will, in turn, be recorded in the indicated Registry) are, in terms of authorization: a) Storage facilities in the context of professional collection, which will be considered storage operations, and b) fixed facilities where waste treatment operations are to be carried out. In these authorized facilities, recovery operations will be undertaken—such as main use as fuel or another method of producing energy, main use as fuel in waste incineration facilities, main use as fuel in gasification, pyrolysis, plasma facilities, and other similar technologies, among others—and disposal operations—such as depositing on or into the ground, treatment in terrestrial environments, land incineration, among others.

Communication: Entities or companies must submit a prior notification to the competent authority of the autonomous community where they are located before starting their activities if they fall under any of the following categories, among others:

Installation, expansion, substantial modification, or relocation of industries or activities generating hazardous waste.

Installation, expansion, substantial modification, or relocation of industries or activities generating more than 1,000 tons/year of non-hazardous waste.
regulatory_requirements.responsible_party: The facilities mentioned in the previous point (for authorization and communication), as well as the natural or legal persons who carry out professional waste collection and treatment operations (only authorization).
regulatory_requirements.key_actions: Obtain the corresponding authorization (comply with the procedure) and make the communication regarding the relevant operation.
regulatory_requirements.deadline: As such, there is no predetermined deadline. However, the chronological order of obtaining the authorization or submitting the notification before carrying out the operation must be followed.
regulatory_requirements.sanctions:
Operating without the corresponding authorization or notification constitutes a very serious or serious infraction, as follows:

Very Serious:

Fine ranging from 100,001 euros to 3,500,000 euros, except in the case of hazardous waste or contaminated soils, where the fine will range from 600,001 euros to 3,500,000 euros.

Disqualification from performing any of the activities provided for in this law for a period of no less than one year and no more than ten years.

Temporary closure, for a period of no less than one year and no more than five years, or definitive, total or partial, closure of facilities or equipment, safeguarding in these cases the rights of workers in accordance with labor legislation.

Revocation of the authorization or suspension of the same for a period of no less than one year and no more than ten years.

b) In the case of serious infractions:

Fine ranging from 2,001 euros to 100,000 euros, except in the case of hazardous waste or contaminated soils, where the fine will range from 20,001 euros to 600,000 euros.

Disqualification from performing any of the activities provided for in this law for a period of less than one year.

Revocation of the authorization or suspension of the same for a period of up to one year.
regulatory_requirements.exemptions:
Individuals or entities disposing of their own non-hazardous waste at the production site or recovering non-hazardous waste may be exempt from authorization.

The Ministry for the Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge will regulate these exemptions per activity type, following a report from the Waste Coordination Commission.

Regulations will specify applicable waste types and quantities, required treatment methods, and ensure safety for human health and the environment.

regulatory_requirements.description: The Royal Decree establishes 3 extended producer responsibility regimes based on the type of packaging: household, commercial, and industrial. Each regime includes a series of obligations to be fulfilled by the obligated parties, which can be the producers, distributors and traders, consumers, and extended producer responsibility systems.

regulatory_requirements.trigger: The activities that trigger this requirement will be those activities that make the subject a product producer for the purposes of the Royal Decree. For producers of household packaging, the key actions are as follows:
Financing the total management of its waste.

Organizing the partial or total management, as decided by local authorities, of its waste.
For producers of commercial packaging, the key actions are as follows:  The financing of the total waste management and the organisation of the total waste management.
These obligations can be fulfilled through an individual Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) system (known as "SIRAP" - "individual system of extended producer responsibility") or a collective one (known as "SCRAP" - "collective system of extended producer responsibility").

The Royal Decree on packaging also establishes obligations for traders and distributors of packaged products -such as participate in deposit-return systems, collaborate in separate collection and provide information to the extended producer responsibility system-, consumers -such us return packaging waste and separate and dispose the non-deposit packaging waste-, and local authorities -such as the total organization of household packaging waste management (unless they specify in agreements that the extended producer responsibility systems will handle total or partial organization) or the recovery and separation of mixed waste).
regulatory_requirements.sanctions: Fines may amount from 100.001 to 3.5 million euros for very serious infringements, 2,001 to 100,000 euros for serious infringements and up to 2,000 euros for minor infringements.

registration_requirements.description:
Companies that have producer responsibility for packaging must report their responsibility to the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency by the 31st of March each year. The report must contain information on the amount of packaging that the producer has provided on the Swedish market during the immediately preceding calendar year. The information must show how much of the packaging is 1. consumer packaging, 2. reusable packaging, 3. reusable consumer packaging, 4. bottles for drinks that are single-use plastic products, and 5. such plastic bottles and metal cans that are part of a return system.

A producer who intends to provide packaging on the Swedish market must, prior to the provision, assign or provide a producer responsibility organization that undertakes to take care of the producer's packaging when it becomes waste.
registration_requirements.trigger:
The following must report to the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency:
- Companies that manufacture or import/bring service packaging into Sweden
- Companies that fill or use all other types of packaging for their business
- Companies that import/bring packaged goods into Sweden
- Companies that manufacture or import/bring single-use cups that are not intended to be filled at the point of sale, such as cups for consumers or offices.
registration_requirements.responsible_party: Companies have responsibility regardless of the amount of packaging that the company provides on the market in Sweden. The company must assign a producer responsibility organisation and ensure that the company has registered its extended producer responsibility to the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency. This includes both domestic and foreign producers, as well as online retailers and distance sellers.
registration_requirements.data_elements:
When registering, you must provide the following information to the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency:
- Name of producer
- Contact details
- Personal or corporate identification number (if not available – tax identification number). If you are a producer and are not established in Sweden but sell directly to final users in Sweden, enter your VAT number instead.
- Which producer responsibility organisation you have hired. If the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency has decided on an exemption according to Chapter 4. Section 2, you will provide that information instead.
- On what basis you are a producer as defined in Chapter 1. Section 6 of the Ordinance (2022:1274) on producer responsibility for packaging. That is, if you by profession;
fill or otherwise use a package (which is not a service package) for the purpose of protecting, presenting or facilitating the handling of a product; bring a packaged product into Sweden; manufacture a packaging in Sweden; bring a package into Sweden; from a country other than Sweden sell a packaged product or packaging to a final user in Sweden
registration_requirements.payment_obligations:
The enforcement fee is SEK 1,250 per producer and calendar year. Producers who have provided less than 1 ton of packaging on the Swedish market shall not pay an enforcement fee to the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency.

However, producers who are obligated to pay littering fees are not covered by the exemption. They pay an enforcement fee regardless of the amount of packaging they have provided.

The littering fees consist of a fixed annual fee and a variable product fee. The annual fee will be paid from 2023 and the product fee from 2024. The fees apply to various single-use plastic packaging, such as plastic bottles, cups and food containers. The fees also apply to plastic wrapping packages that are common for ice cream, sweets and snacks.

As a producer, you pay a compensation (packaging fee) to the producer responsibility organization you have hired. The fee shall, among other things, cover costs for the collection and treatment of packaging waste. The fee takes into account the amount of packaging the company provides on the market in Sweden. The fee also takes into account the material recyclability of the packging.
registration_requirements.sanctions:
If a company has not complied with the legislation, it may lead to an environmental sanction fee. An environmental sanction fee is an administrative fee that is charged by the enforcement authority when an individual or a company has committed infringements against certain provisions according to the Environmental Code, or against provisions that have been decided on the basis of the Environmental Code.

In the event of infringements of certain provisions, you shall pay an environmental sanction fee. Different infringements will result in different environmental sanction fees. The fees range between SEK 5000-50 000 (approx. 500-5000 euro). See Chapter 11. Section 19-22 Ordinance (2012:259) on environmental sanction fees.

If a producer has not hired or provided a producer responsibility organization, an environmental sanction fee of SEK 30,000 may be charged. This applies from 1 January 2024.

From 1 January 2024, the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency can also decide on an environmental sanction fee for late registration.
registration_requirements.exemptions:
In individual cases, the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency may grant an exemption from the requirement to hire or provide a producer responsibility organisation. Before a decision is announced, the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency must give the producer responsibility organisations an opportunity to comment. Exemption can be granted for a certain period in the following cases:

- If all packaging provided by the producer is to be sorted as hazardous waste when it becomes waste.
- If the producer can ensure that at least 90 % of the packaging that the producer provides on the market rotates in a market-driven system for re-use and is taken care of by the system when it becomes waste. The Swedish Environmental Protection Agency's interpretation is that the possibility of exemption from the requirement applies if the producer only provides reusable packaging.


If the producer provides packaging that is not reusable, the producer cannot be exempted from the requirement. A producer who provides both reusable packaging and disposable packaging must therefore hire or provide a producer responsibility organisation.

regulatory_requirements.key_actions:
The Environmental Code contains a number of general rules of consideration. The most important of them are the precautionary principle, the polluter pays principle, the product choice principle and principles regarding resource management, recycling and suitable localisation of activities and measures.

The rules have a preventive effect since they oblige every operator of an environmentally hazardous activity to assay the environmental effects of its activities. That is before starting up a new activity, as well as continuously as long as the activity is ongoing.

Supervisory and licensing authorities use the general rules of consideration as basis for their decisions. They are mandated to decide on injunctions, bans, permit conditions etc. to assure the fulfillment of the general rules of consideration. As a result, the scope of these rules continuously become much more specific through regulations or decisions in individual cases.
regulatory_requirements.sanctions:
Most penalties for environmental crimes are gathered in the Environmental code. In addition to the penalties, there are also sanction charges for more specific acts. The penalties are decided by the supervisory authorities but can be appealed to court. If the operator continues to commit the sanctioned act there is a possibility for the supervisory authority to decide on a sanction charge with an increased amount. The sanction charges are an effective instrument to give a rapid response to infringements of the environmental protection provisions.

The size of the fee must be stated in the regulations. The fee must amount to a minimum of SEK 1,000 and a maximum of SEK 1,000,000. When the amount of the fee is determined, the seriousness of the violation and the importance of the provision to which the violation refers must be taken into account.
